author: David Hendricks
title: Is Jack Reacher’s tough-guy facade finally cracking?
text:
Image 1 of / 1 1
Is Jack Reacher’s tough-guy facade finally cracking? 1 / 1 Back to Gallery Apparently, no place exists where evil cannot be rooted out by Jack Reacher.
Reacher, the protagonist in all of Lee Child ’s thrillers, goes anywhere because he lives nowhere and just drifts.
In “Make Me,” the 20th Jack Reacher novel, he steps off a train at Mother’s Rest, a speck of a passenger-train stop in a tiny town in the middle of wheat country.
Reacher imagines the place’s name might come from a mother’s graveyard from wagon train days, but no one seems to knows where the name originated.
Just showing up arouses suspicion, though.
Reacher notices several people, including a young boy, reporting his position by telephone as he walks about Mother’s Rest.
More Information Make Me
By Lee Child
Delacorte Press, $28.99
He soon teams up with an ex-FBI agent, Michelle Chang , now a private investigator, who is searching for her missing partner on a case.
The reader knows more than Reacher and Chang for much of the book because the first pages reveal the missing investigator already is dead and buried.
The tension tightens as the surveillance continues at Mother’s Rest and Reacher and Chang chase threadbare clues around the nation about what might have happened.
One such clue is a written note mentioning “200 dead.”
The mystery deepens as other people arriving at Mother’s Rest by train are treated far better than Reacher and Chang.
That’s as far as a review should reveal about the plot, but readers can be assured all the trademark Reacher actions will follow: physical violence, close calls and vigilante justice as the truth slowly emerges. An overwhelming, forceful climax also is in store, as usual.
The smooth narrative is driven by wise-cracking dialogue. The type of hidden evil doesn’t begin to emerge until nearly two-thirds of the way through the 402-page book. Readers may learn something new about the existence of an aspect of daily modern life, but saying what that is would be a spoiler.
Longtime Child fans may have noticed that Reacher, as a character, never changes or grows within each book — or from book to book.
He’s the same tough guy with a keen sense of justice and a winning way with women that he was in the first novel, “Killing Floor,” to the 19th, “Personal.”
In “Make Me,” hints appear that Reacher may be changing.
The cumulative physical altercations over the years are starting to take their toll. Reacher is not well at the end of “Make Me,” a turn of events that may factor into future stories.
